choices.text: Same regimen is given in all patient
Streptomycin always given in first two months

questions.text: True about DOTS:
questions.solution:
DOTS

  • DOTS is directly observed treatment short course.
  • In DOTS during the intensive phase of treatment a health worker are other trained person watches as the patients swallows the drugs in his presence.
  • During continuation phase the patient is issued med-icine for one week in multiblister combipack of which the first dose is swallowed by the patient in the pres-ence of health worker or trained person.
  • The consumption of medicine in the continuation phase is also checked by return of empty multiblister combipack when patient come to collect medicine for the next week
  • In this programme attemate day treatment is used.
  • Patient compliance is critically important throughout the prescribed period of treatment. All other consid-eration are secondary.
  • Drugs are given category wise, same regimen is not given to all patient.
  • Streptomycin is given in catgory II only.
  • In category-1 new sputum smear, positive cases spu-tum examination is done in 2,4 and 6 months.

questions.text: Revised strategies of National Programme for Control of Blindness include all except
questions.solution: Revised strategies of NPCB: To make NPCB more comprehensive by, Strengthening services for other causes of blindness like corneal blindness and refractive errors in school children Improving follow up services of cataract operated persons Treating other causes of blindness like glaucoma. To strengthen participation of voluntary organizations To shift from eye camp approach to fixed facility surgical approach To enhance coverage of eye services in tribal & underserved areas To expand World Bank project activities Construction of dedicated eye OTs and eye wards Training of eye surgeons Modern cataract surgery Supply of ophthalmic equipment.

questions.text: True about Sentinel surveillance of HIV/AIDS by NACO are all except:
questions.solution:
HIV Sentinel Surveillance (HSS) system in India

  • Cross-sectional facility and Targeted Intervention (TI) based HIV sero-prevalence surveys at regular intervals among selected population groups (Senti-nel groups)
  • Trends in HIV infection are monitored over the period of time by group and by site
  • Proxy for general population in HSS: Pregnant females attending AN clinics
    During NACP-IV, HIV Sentinel Surveillance will be conducted once in two years ('Biennial surveil - lance') so that adequate time is spent on in-depth analysis and modeling, epidemiological research and use of surveillance data for programmatic purposes

questions.text: Acute flaccid paralysis is reported in a child aged:
questions.solution: Acute Flaccid Paralysis (AFP) Surveillance is used to identify reservoirs of wild poliovirus transmission in National Polio Surveillance Project Acute: rapid progression from onset to maxi-mum paralysis Flaccid: loss of muscle tone, floppy - as opposed to spastic or rigid Paralysis: weakness, loss of voluntary movement Acute Flaccid Paralysis (AFP): Any child less than 15 years age who has sudden onset of flaccid paralysis or paralytic illness in a person of any age when polio is suspected

questions.text: Rashtriya Swasthya Bima Yojana, all are true except
questions.solution:
Rashtriya Swasthya Bima Yojana

  • Synonym: National Health Insurance Scheme (NHIS)
  • Beneficiaries: Below poverty line families

questions.text: The National Population Policy 2000 aims to achieve Tota1 Fertility Rate of 2.1 by the year:
questions.solution: Immediate objective: To address the unmet needs for contraception, health care infrastructure, and health personnel, and to provide integrated service delivery for basic reproductive and child health care. Mid-term objective: To bring the TFR to replacement levels (TFR = 2.1) by 2010. Long term objective: To achieve a stable population by 2045.

questions.text: India is in which stage of demographic cycle:
questions.solution:
Demographic cycle - The history of world population since 1650 suggests that there is a demographic cycle of 5 stages through which a nation passes:

  1. FIRST STAGE (High stationary) This stage is characterized by a high birth rate and a high death rate which cancel each other and the population remains stationary. India was in this stage till 1920.
  2. SECOND STAGE (Early expanding) The death rate begins to decline, while the birth rate remains unchanged. Many countries in South Asia, and Africa are in this phase. Birth rates have increased in some of these countries possibly as a result of improved health conditions, and shortening periods of breast-feeding.
  3. THIRD STAGE (Late expanding) The death rate declines still further, and the birth rate tends to fall. The population continues to grow because births exceed deaths. India has entered this phase. In a number of developing countries (e.g., China, Singapore) birth rates have declined rapidly.
  4. FOURTH STAGE (Low stationary) This stage is characterized by a low birth and low death rate with the result that the population becomes stationary. Zero population growth has already been recorded in Austria during 1980-85. Growth rates as little as 0.1 were recorded in UK, Denmark, Sweden and Belgium during 1980-85.

questions.text: Which of the following is contraindicated in pregnancy for treatment of uncomplicated P. Falciparum.
questions.solution:
Pregnant women with uncomplicated P. Falciparum should be treated as follows

1st trimester- quinine

2nd Trimester- ACT

Primaquine is contraindicated in pregnancy

choices.text: Enhanced surveillance of Acute Flaccid Paralysis

questions.text: Which of the following is strategy for eradication of Poliomyelitis
questions.solution:
Different strategies for eradication of polio are based on epidemiology of poliomyelitis and characteristics of polio vaccines. In case of poliomyelitis there is only one clinical case for 100 or 100 in-apparent infections. Therefore polio eradication strategies involve universal immunization. Various strategies for eradication of polio are-

  1. Routine Immunization
  2. Supplementary Immunization
  3. Enhanced surveillance of Acute Flaccid Paralysis
  4. Targeted mop-up campaigns

questions.solution: Key Indicators in Kala Azar elimination are as follows

questions.text: Beneficiaries of Applied Nutrition Programme:
questions.solution:
Applied Nutrition Programme was started in 1960 in two states. In 1973 it was extended to cover all the states. The objective of the programme were:

  1. To make the people conscious of their nutritional needs.
  2. To increase the production and consumption of nutritious foods through involvement of the community.

To provide supplementary nutrition to vulnerable groups through locally produced foods The intended beneficiaries include children 3-6 years and pregnant and lactating mothers

choices.text: Carry out initial surveys in endemic districts to assess prevalence, type of infection and vectors
Responsible for population survey, treatment of cases and carriers

questions.text: Filaria survey units has following functions
questions.solution:
There are 27 survey units, 206 control units, 199 filaria clinics and 3 rural filarial control projects

Filaria Survey units-carry out initial surveys in endemic districts to assess prevalence, type of infection and vectors

Filaria clinics -responsible for population survey, treatment of cases and carriers

Filaria Control Units -carry out antimalarial measures, also responsible for monitoring of mosquitoes breeding places for larvae, pupae and vector density.

questions.text: Which of the following is not part of Reproductive and Child Health Programme after the paradigm shift in 1997?
questions.solution:
• Review of National Family Welfare Programme was done in 1994-1995, which showed that the system of contraceptive targets and cash incentives resulted in inflation of performance figures, neglect of needs of the client and quality of services.
  • Major emphasis was on sterilization and the needs of young couples for spacing were ignored. The major recommendation of this review was to replace method specific contraceptive targets and incentives with reproductive health indicators.
  • In April 1996 after pilot projects of 18 districts and 2 states (Kerala and Tamil nadu) National Family Welfare Programme adopted Target Free Approach.
  • In September 1997, it was renamed more appropriately as Community Needs Assessment Approach.
  • In October 1997, Reproductive and Child Health Programme was formally launched by GOI with a paradigm shift from Target Oriented to Target Free Approach.

choices.text: L1: minimum three normal deliveries per month
L2: minimum ten deliveries per month including management of complications
L3: minimum twenty to fifty deliveries per month including C section

questions.text: Regarding term 'Delivery Points' in RMNCH+A which of the following is true?
questions.solution:
• The provision of services for delivery care in a health facility generally serves as an important indicator to assess whether the facility is optimally functional or not. The concept of 'delivery point' emerges from this presumption.
  • Among the health facilities designated as L1, L2 and L3, there are some facilities which are conducting deliveries above a minimum bench mark (minimum 3 normal deliveries per month at L1; minimum 10 deliveries per month, including management of complications, at L2; minimum 20-50 deliveries per month including C-section at L3).
  • These are designated as delivery points.
  • According to the government mandate, these facilities should be the first to be strengthened for providing comprehensive RMNCH Services.
  • This should be supported by a referral transport system that reaches the patient within 30 minutes of receiving a call and the health facility within the next 30 minutes.
  • The long-term goal should be to establish and operationalize Basic Emergency Obstetric Care and Comprehensive Emergency Obstetric Care Centres as per the expected delivery load in the state and district.

questions.text: National Leprosy Control Programme was launched in:
questions.solution:
• Important Milestones In NLEP In India
  • 1955 Government of India launched National Leprosy Control Programme.
  • 1983 Government of India launched NLEP and introduced MDT.
  • 1993 - 2000 World Bank supported NLEP I.
  • 2001 - 2004 World Bank supported NLEP II.
  • 2005 (Jan.) NLEP continued with Government of India funds & donor partners support.
  • 2005 (Dec.) India achieved elimination as a public health problem.
  • 2012 - Special action plan for 209 high endemic districts in 16 States/UTs

questions.text: National Programme for Control of Blindness and Prevention of Visual Impairment was launched in
questions.solution:
• National Programme for Control of Blindness was launched in the year 1976
  • 100% Centrally Sponsored scheme with the goal to reduce the prevalence of blindness from 1.4% to 0.3%.
  • Various activities/initiatives undertaken during the Five Year Plans under NPCB are targeted towards achieving the goal of reducing the prevalence of blindness to 0.3% by the year 2020.

Goals & Objectives of NPCB in the XII Plan

1) To reduce the backlog of blindness through identification and treatment of blind at primary, secondary and tertiary levels.

2) Develop and strengthen the strategy of NPCB for Eye Health and prevention of visual impairment; through provision of comprehensive eye care services and quality service delivery.

3) Strengthening and upgradation of RIOs to become centre of excellence in various sub-specialities of ophthalmology

4) Strengthening the existing and developing additional human resources and infrastructure facilities for providinghigh quality comprehensive Eye Carein all Districts of the country;

5) To enhancecommunity awareness on eye care and lay stress on preventive measures;

6) Increase and expand research for prevention of blindness and visual impairment

7) To secure participation of Voluntary Organizations/Private Practitioners in eye care

questions.text: Integrated Child Protection Scheme is under which ministry?
questions.solution:
• The ICPS is a Centrally sponsored program under Ministry of Women & Child Development Government of India.
  • For child protection, being implemented across the country from 2009-10.
  • It was conceived at the beginning of the XI Plan period, when children were placed at the 'centre of development' by the XI Plan and protection of children from abuse and exploitation was stated to be integral to their holistic growth and development.

choices.text: 85% reduction in new HIV infections
70% reduction in new HIV infections
75% reduction in new HIV infections
80% reduction in new HIV infections

questions.text: By 2020, the focus of the national programme will be on achieving
questions.solution:
• As per National Strategic Plan on HIV/AIDS and STI, 2017-24 By 2020, the focus of the national programme will be on achieving the following fast track targets:
    1. 75% reduction in new HIV infections,
    2. 90-90-90: 90% of those who are HIV positive in the country know their status, 90% of those who know their status are on treatment and 90% of those who are on treatment experience effective viral load suppression,
    3. Elimination of mother-to-child transmission of HIV and Syphilis, and
    4. Elimination of stigma and discrimination Paving Way for an AIDS Free India
  • By 2024, the further achievements envisaged are
    1. 80% reduction in new HIV infections,
    2. Ensuring that 95% of those who are HIV positive in the country know their status, 95% of those who know their status are on treatment and 95% of those who are on treatment experience effective viral load suppression
  • To this effect, two key achievements in early 2017 to Ending of AIDS by 2030 include the enactment of the HIV/AIDS Bill as a law protecting the rights of people living with and affected by HIV as well as the announcement and implementation of the Test and Treat policy in line with global guidelines.

questions.text: Full form of IPHS is:
questions.solution:
• IPHS are a set of uniform standards envisaged to improve the quality of health care delivery in the country.
  • The IPHS documents have been revised keeping in view the changing protocols of the existing programmes and introduction of new programmes especially for Non-Communicable Diseases. Last time they were revised in 2012.
  • Flexibility is allowed to suit the diverse needs of the States and regions.
  • These IPHS guidelines will act as the main driver for continuous improvement in quality and serve as the bench mark for assessing the functional status of health facilities

choices.text: All countries of the region should maintain polio free status for at least 5 consecutive years.
Absence of wild polio virus from the communities as indicated by stool samples from normal children and where appropriate from waste water from high risk populations Afghanistan
Appropriate measures established to deal with importations

questions.text: Which Of The Following Is Not Criteria For Polio Free Certification
questions.solution:
• As per WHO policy only a WHO region, and not any individual country, will be certifies as polio free. Criteria for certification of any region as polio free requires
    1. All countries of the region should maintain polio free status for at least 3 consecutive years.
    2. Absence of wild polio virus from the communities as indicated by stool samples from normal children and where appropriate from waste water from high risk populations
    3. Appropriate measures established to deal with importations

questions.text: Pulse Polio Immunization Campaign was launched for first time in India in
questions.solution:
• With the global initiative of eradication of polio in 1988 following World Health Assembly resolution in 1988, Pulse Polio Immunization programme was launched in India in 1995.
  • The Pulse Polio Initiative was started with an objective of achieving hundred per cent coverage under Oral Polio Vaccine. It aimed to immunize children through improved social mobilization, plan mop-up operations in areas where poliovirus has almost disappeared and maintain high level of morale among the public.
  • Children in the age group of 0-5 years administered polio drops during National and Sub-national immunization rounds (in high risk areas) every year.
  • About 172 million children are immunized during each National Immunization Day (NID).

choices.text: This Act has been revoked particularly in plague epidemic recently
This act still holds good in modern times
Violation of any of the provisions of this Act is can only lead to a fine
Person who is inspecting, is empowered to determine the process and authority to take responsibility of all expenses

questions.text: Which of the following statement is true pertaining to epidemic disease act?
questions.solution:
• EPIDEMIC DISEASE ACT 1871. The Act provides power to exercise for the control and to prevent any epidemic or spread of epidemic in the states or country.
  • The states may authorize any of its officers or agency to take such measures if the state feel that the public at large is threatened with an outbreak of any dangerous epidemic (Sec.2).
  • Person who is inspecting, is empowered to determine the process and authority to take responsibility of all expenses incurred in compensation, traveling, temporary accommodation, segregation of infected person, etc.
  • Violation of any of the provisions of this Act is punishable under Sec 188 of the IPC. Over a period of time India has witnessed many epidemics and pandemics.
  • This Act has been revoked particularly in H1N1 pandemic recently.
  • It is realized that there is need to expand the scope of this Act including disease prevention and control.
  • This Act should be repealed with more comprehensive Public Health Act.

questions.text: Integrated Vector Management is done by using identical vector control methods to control following except
questions.solution:
IVM is a rational decision-making process for the optimal use of resources for vector control. The approach seeks to improve the efficacy, cost-effectiveness, ecological soundness and sustainability of disease-vector control. The ultimate goal is to prevent the transmission of vector-borne diseases such as malaria, dengue, Japanese encephalitis, leishmaniasis, schistosomiasis and Chagas disease.

Rationale

Driving forces behind a growing interest in IVM include the need to overcome challenges experienced with conventional single-intervention approaches to vector control as well as recent opportunities for promoting multi-sectoral approaches to human health.

IVM will be implemented involving

  1. entomological surveillance in sentinel and random sites at monthly intervals;
  2. appropriate use of insecticides for supervised IRS with full support (including spray wages) from NVBDCP;
  3. scaling-up use of LLIN;
  4. treatment of community owned bed-nets;
  5. intensified anti-larval operations in urban and peri-urban areas within the states /districts;
  6. scaling up use of larvivorous fish with exploring outsourcing to NGOs under PPP model; and
  7. promotion of source-reduction, minor engineering etc. by involvement of panchayati raj institutions at village level

choices.text: Standards on treatment, measures for ensuring adherence to drug treatment, record keeping and monitoring of the response
Standards of public health and prevention
Addressing HIV-TB Co-infection and other co-morbid conditions

questions.text: International Standards of care- Standard 7-13 are related to
questions.solution:
The International Standards for Tuberculosis were first formulated in 2009 and have undergone third revision in 2014. These describe an internationally accepted level of care that all practitioners, public and private should follow in dealing with people who have or suspected of having TB.

There is set of 21 standards-

Standards 1-6 Pulmonary and extra pulmonary tuberculosis

Standards 7-13 Standards on treatment, measures for ensuring adherence to drug treatment, record keeping and monitoring of the response

Standards 14-17Addressing HIV-TB Co-infection and other co-morbid conditions

Standards 18-21 Standards of public health and prevention

questions.text: Mahila Arogya Samiti would be set up for every:
questions.solution:
• MAS in one of the key interventions under National Health Mission aimed at promoting community participation in health at all levels, including planning, implementing and monitoring of health programmes.
  • MAS is expected to take collective action on issues related to Health, Nutrition, Water, Sanitation and social determinants at the slum level.
  • It is envisaged as being central to local collective action, which would gradually develop to the process of decentralized health planning.

Mahila Arogya Samiti (MAS):

  1. Local women's collective with an elected Chairperson and a Secretary.
  2. Covers approximately 50-100 households in slum and slum like settlements.
  3. Addresses local issues related to Health, Nutrition, Water, Sanitation and social determinants of health at slum level.
  4. Facilitated by the ASHA who acts as the Member Secretary.

The major objectives of MAS are to:

  1. Provide a platform for convergent action on social determinants and all public services directly or indirectly related to health.
  2. Provide a mechanism for the community to voice health needs, experiences and issues with access to health services.
  3. Generate community level awareness on locally relevant health issues and to promote the acceptance of best practices in health by the community.
  4. Focus on preventive and promotive health care activities and management of untied fund.
  5. Support and facilitate the work of community service providers like ASHA and other frontline workers who form a crucial interface between the community and health institutions.
  6. Provide an institutional mechanism for the community to be informed of various health programmes and other government initiatives and to participate in the planning and implementation of these programmes, leading to better health outcomes.

Organize or facilitate community level services and referral linkages for health services

questions.text: Annapurna and Antyodaya Anna Yojna are not under?
questions.solution:
Annapurna anAntyodaya Anna Yojna are under Ministry of Agriculture, Consumer Affairs, Food and Public Distribution.

Annapurna scheme was launched by Ministry of Rural development in 2000-01.

  • Destitute senior citizens of 65 years age or above who are eligible for old age pension under National Old Age Pension scheme but are not getting the pension are covered.
  • Under this scheme 10kgs of food grains per person per month are supplied free of cost.
  • From 2002-03 it has been transferred to state plan along with National Social Assistance Programme comprising National Old Age Scheme and National family Benefit scheme.
  • The Implementation of the Scheme at state level rests with the respective states and UTs.

Antyodaya Anna Yojna was launched in December 2000.

  • Under the scheme 1 crore poorest families out of BPl families covered under Targeted Public Distribution System have been identified.
  • Coverage under the scheme has been expanded thrice times since then; during 2003-04, 2004-05 and 2005-06 covering additional 50 lakh households each time to be identified from BPL families.
  • Thus total coverage under AAy was 2.50 crore.

These families are given food grains at highly subsidized rates eg wheat at Rs2 per kg, and riceRs3 per kg, 35 kg being supplied per family per month

choices.text: Reduce the neonatal mortality rates to 21/1000 by 2020
Reduce the neonatal mortality rates to 22 /1000 by 2023
Reduce the neonatal mortality rates to 24/1000 by 2017
Reduce the neonatal mortality rates to 15/1000 by 2025

questions.text: Which of the following is not true for India New Born Action Plan?
questions.solution:
India commits to eliminates preventable deaths of new-borns and stillbirths.

  • The commitments in the India Newborn Action Plan (INAP) were developed to align with the global ENAP (Every new born action plan).
  • India however aspires to achieve the global ENAP targets by 2030 five years ahead of the global deadline with all the states to individually achieve the targets by the end of 2035.
  • The targets proposed in the INAP reducing preventable new-born deaths and preventable stillbirths to single digits, i.e., fewer than 10 per 1,000 live births by 2030, with intermediate targets for 2017, 2020 and 2025 require universal, equitable, and high-quality coverage of comprehensive care for every woman and new-born in the country.
  • INAP envisages bringing down neonatal mortality rates to 24, 21 and 15 per 1000 live births by 2017, 2020 and 2025.
  • The INAP is expected to serve as a roadmap that redefines and focuses national and subnational strategies and actions until 2020, when India will review the progress achieved and revise its strategy accordingly.
  • INAP has two goals:
    • Goal 1: Ending Preventable Newborn Deaths to achieve Single Digit NMR by 2030, with all the states to individually achieve this target by 2035.

Goal 2: Ending Preventable Stillbirths to achieve Single Digit SBR by 2030, with all the states to individually achieve this target by 2035.

questions.text: Saathiya Slaah App is for?
questions.solution:
• One of the key interventions under the Rashtriya Kishor Swasthya Karyakram (RKSK) program is introduction of the Peer Educators (Saathiyas) who act as a catalyst for generating demand for the adolescent health services and imparting age appropriate knowledge on key adolescent health issues to their peer groups.
  • In order to equip the Saathiyas in doing so, the Health Ministry has launched the Saathiya Resource Kit (including 'Saathiya Salah' Mobile App).
  • It acts as a ready information source for the adolescents in case they are unable to interact with the Peer Educators.
  • The mobile app is also linked to another important piece of cost-effective information platform of a toll-free Saathiya Helpline (1800-233-1250) which will act as an e-counselor.
  • While the short films will be played by the Peer Educators at their group meetings, the activity book and games will bring about discussion and resolve adolescent queries.

Encashing on mobile technology, the shy adolescents or those unable to interact with the peer educators due to family reasons, can access the information through the free mobile app as well the toll free helpline.

questions.text: Which of the following programme is related to improvement in quality of care during child birth?
questions.solution:
Government of India (GoI) launched a strategic initiative 'Dakshata' in the year 2015. The program was designed with a vision to rapidly improve the quality of care during childbirth in the public health facilities to achieve the goal of maternal and newborn mortality reduction in India.

Initially introduced in the six high-priority states, this program was supposed to be scaled-up in other states of the country. Even within these six states, the program was initially focused on the high-priority districts (HPD).

Dakshata has four main components

  1. Improving skills of health workers in the key life-saving practices.
  2. Improving availability of resources essential for performing these life-saving practices.
  3. Implementing strategies for transfer of learning into practice.
  4. Improved use of data for decision-making and action.

Currently, the program is being implemented in more than 1000 facilities across 98 districts in the states of Rajasthan, Madhya Pradesh, Odisha, Maharashtra, Andhra Pradesh, Jharkhand and Telangana, with technical assistance (TA) by implementation partners such as JHPIEGO. Early results from these states show improvements in adherence to safe practices amongst facility-based health workers

questions.text: Mission Sampark is related to:
questions.solution:
Mission Sampark -

The Government of India is committed to working towards providing universal access to comprehensive, equitable, stigma free, quality care support and treatment services to all the people living with HIV.

Provision of life saving Antiretroviral drugs, free of cost with public health approach, is one of the major pillars response to AIDS.

A landmark decision was taken by the Government to launch Test and Treat Policy, under which all PL HIV are offered ART irrespective of CD 4 count, clinical stage, age or population.

  • Under Mission Sampark, duplicates within the system will be identified, silent transfer outs between the states and GIS mapping to intensify the efforts.
  • Based on this a clear road map will be prepared to reach out to the people who know their positive status but are not on ART.
  • Second step would be Contact Drive. LFUs will be offered on site counselling services, linkages to existing social beneficiary schemes and any medical service at ART centre.

With this endeavour, the government strives to bring all PLHIV under ART services and ensure adherence for achieving the set goal of ending AIDS by 2030.
